metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose

facts.text: First respondent purchased the entire Touzi No. 341 of the 24-Parganas Collectorate at a revenue sale held on January 9, 1942.

As purchaser, respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859 the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under-tenants with certain exceptions.
In exercise of that right, respondent gave notices of ejectment and brought a suit in 1946 to evict certain under-tenants, including the second respondent, and to recover possession of the lands.
Suit was decreed against the second respondent who preferred an appeal to the District Judge, 24-Parganas, contending his undertenure came within one of the exceptions in section 37.
While appeal pending, West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 introduced in Assembly on March 23, 1950; passed and came into force on March 15, 1950.
Amending Act substituted new section 37; section 7 provided all pending suits, appeals abate unless resulted in delivery of possession.
Respondent contended section 7 void as abridging fundamental rights under article 19(1)(f) and 31; moved High Court under article 228.
High Court (Harries C.J. and Banerjee J.) by judgment dated 22nd March, 1951 declared section 7 unconstitutional and void; returned case to District Court.
Subordinate Judge decreed suit for ejectment on 14th February, 1949; appeal Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949 filed 25th March, 1949.
High Court directed appeal transferred under article 228 on 18th December, 1950; heard as Reference No. 4 of 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 is void as abridging fundamental rights under article 19(1)(f) read with 19(5) or under article 31.
Scope of article 19(1)(f) and its distinction from article 31; whether right to annul under-tenures is protected under 19(1)(f) or amounts to deprivation under article 31.

petitioner_arguments.text: If right to annul under-tenures is property under article 19(1)(f), it is also property under article 31(1); deprived by authority of law (section 7), hence lawful.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 31(1); Chiranjit Lal Chowdhury's case; Gopalan's case

petitioner_arguments.text: Nullification is reasonable restriction on enjoyment of property in interests of general public, considering hardships in urban areas due to speculative purchases.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 19(1)(f) and 19(5); Statement of Objects and Reasons

respondent_arguments.text: Retrospective deprivation of vested right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants without abatement of purchase price infringes article 19(1)(f); not reasonable restriction under 19(5).
Right conferred by old section 37 is itself property; taken away without compensation violating article 31(2).

court_reasoning.text: Article 19(1)(f) protects general freedom/capacity to acquire, hold, dispose of property as basic right of citizen; concrete rights to specific property protected under article 31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 19(1)(f) has no application; deals with natural rights, not specific property rights.

court_reasoning.text: Article 31(1) requires deprivation only by authority of law, protecting against executive; clause 2 elaborates for acquisition/taking possession with compensation/public purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clauses 1 and 2 read together; no police power conferred arbitrarily.

court_reasoning.text: Abridgement of right to annul under-tenures not substantial deprivation under article 31; purchaser gets compensating right to enhance rents; not acquisition or taking possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrospective operation enlarges tenant protection with safeguards; not deprivation.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in applying article 19(1)(f); circumstances (urban hardship, speculation) justify as reasonable if under 19(5), but not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions reasonable considering objects, urgency (ordinance passed).

holdings.text: Section 7 of amending Act does not violate article 19(1)(f) or article 31; High Court judgment declaring it unconstitutional is wrong.
Article 19(1)(f) protects capacity to own property generally; specific property rights under article 31.

precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on article 31(1) and (2); obiter on deprivation by authority of law.
Rejection of due process; scheme of Constitution on fundamental rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. V.G. Row
Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights to property; validity of section 7 tested against these.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act, 1859
statutes_cited.relevance: Right of revenue sale purchaser to annul under-tenures; substituted by amending Act.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Substituted new section 37; abated pending proceedings retrospectively.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of High Court set aside declaring section 7 unconstitutional. Case to proceed without abatement under section 7.
outcome.costs: First respondent to pay costs of appeal to appellant here and in lower court.

key_quotes.text: Sub-clause (f) of clause (1) of article 19 seems analogous to clause (1) of article 17 of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights: 'Everyone has the right to own property alone as well as in association with others' and article 31 to clause (2) of article 17: 'No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his property.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes general right under Art 19(1)(f) from specific protection under Art 31.

key_quotes.text: Broadly speaking it may be said that an abridgement would be so substantial as to amount to a deprivation within the meaning of article 31 if, in effect, it withheld the property from the possession and enjoyment of the owner, or seriously impaired its use and enjoyment by him, or materially reduced its value.
key_quotes.speaker: court
